712413f-a.text:
37th Street, Lexington Avenue, to Park Avenue. (Before Reconstruction).
President Borough of Manhattan.

712411f-a.text:
152-162 East 37th Street, on the south side, East of Lexington Avenue; a new apartment building is nearing completion on the site of three old houses, Nos. 156-l60 East 37th Street.
1924.

720957f-a.text:
Lexington Avenue, north from East 37th Street, showing prominently the westerly frontage. The Lindley House was erected (in 1940) at the corner site on the
left.
April 13, 1924
Standard Photographic Service
Gift of Borough President of Manhattan

NEG. #4841

720958f-a.text:
Lexington Avenue, west side, south from East 38th to 37th Streets. The far corner of this block front was demolished in 1940 and replaced by the Lindley House, an apartment structure. Otherwise these remain as shown
with the exception of the iron railings.
April 13, 1924
Standard Photographic Service
Gift of Borough President of Manhattan

720955f.text:
Lexington Avenue, at the N. E. corner of East 37th Street (right). showing the newly constructed Hotel White at that location.
About 1925.
Underwood and Enderwood
No reproductions.

720956f-a.text:
Lexington Avenue (right), at the N.W. corner of East 37th Street, showing a group of houses that are to be replaced by a modern apartment building. Same being the 3-structures (Note 296 to 300) forming the corner plot of 60x90, according to a report listed in the New York Times of March 9, 1.38. This new structure will be 14-stories high and contain 94 suites. This is under construction in March, 1940 and will be known as
Lindley House.
March, 1938
George D. Chinn

1507767-a.title: 37th Street (East) - Lexington Avenue, northwest corner -
1507767-a.folder: 37th Street (East) - Lexington Avenue, northwest corner -, Manhattan, NY

712412f-a.text:
37th Street, north side, from Lexington Avenue to and including Park. Nos. 117 and 119 have just been sold by Mrs. 2. M. Peters after having been in the family for fifty-four years. No. 119
is the 2-story garage.
October 12, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
According to the New York Times of March 29, 1938 the structures at the right, comprising a portion of a 60E90 plot at the N.W. corner of Lexington Ave. and East 37th Street, will be demolished and a new 14-story apartment house ereoted there at a cost of 500,000.
